If u wanna try this orginal recipe.. u have to come India lol.. here in my

comments.author: Puja Agarwal

comments.text:
+juffurey exactly! As well, I have some Indian friends and I've been to 
their houses for dinner and ALL of them use canned tomato, simply for the 
fact that it's simple and tastes the same as cooked tomato prior to the 
spices.
comments.author: Jessica Lyon

comments.text:
+Jessica Lyon seriously, it's like if I were saying that there is not a 
single decent western cuisine restaurant in all of india.
comments.author: juffurey

comments.text:
+seanmcbride1 okay, but don't ridicule the indian chef on here for using 
them. it may not be the most traditional way, but you can still make very 
good dishes with them. good canned tomato puree, paste, or whole, cooked or 
uncooked, should only have one ingredient: tomatoes. maybe salt. without 
preservatives it still has a shelf life of a couple years.  I mentioned 
Italian food as an example, but it is a general rule, regardless of the 
cuisine. not all canned goods are terrible.
comments.author: juffurey

comments.text:
+seanmcbride1 Not always. I've been to similar restaurants and those are 
crap, yes. That doesn't mean all of them are.  =]
comments.author: Jessica Lyon

comments.text:
+Jessica Lyon I went to this Indian restaurant in Toronto, turns out it was 
being run by Pakistanis, tried the butter chicken, and it was crap, sadly 
what's being sold in North America and the UK in the name of Indian food is 
nothing but a travesty. Any time you decide to visit India, try the food in 
New Delhi the capital, it's the best food you'll ever taste.
comments.author: seanmcbride1

comments.text:
+juffurey Italian and Indian cuisines are two different things. 
canned tomato has preservatives in it. The video is about Butter Chicken 
and I was talking about authentic butter chicken, and one would never use 
canned tomato to make butter chicken, you could use it but no genuine 
cook uses it here in India, the tomatoes need to be cooked before 
they're pureed with a bunch of spices and that's how one makes butter 
chicken. Trust me I know a thing or two about Butter Chicken, I come from 
the city where this Dish was invented, New Delhi.
comments.author: seanmcbride1

comments.text:
+Xenophile C The one we went to was Queen W/ King W area. I've been 
looking, but I can't remember or recognize the name of it =[
comments.author: Jessica Lyon

comments.text:
+Jessica Lyon on blood. In between ossington and Christie. Closer to 
Christie though.
comments.author: Xenophile C

comments.text:
+Xenophile C Haha I don't even remember the name of it- my friend took me 
there and it was great. Where is it?
comments.author: Jessica Lyon

comments.text:
+Jessica Lyon lollll ya it's one of those reasons that doesn't have to be 
said. I know 2 good ones in Toronto. Have u tried Banjara?
comments.author: Xenophile C

comments.text:
+Xenophile C There's a reason all the good ones are in Brampton! ;) We'll 
always choose to go to Brampton for Indian Food, but there are a couple of 
good ones in Toronto. =]
comments.author: Jessica Lyon

comments.text:
+seanmcbride1 there's nothing wrong with canned tomato, if it's just puree 
or plain stewed tomatoes. top Italian chefs use canned tomatoes too. it's 
actually better than using fresh most of the time because it's made from 
tomatoes fully ripe off the vine instead of plucking them when they're 
unripe and letting them ripen at the market or at home.
comments.author: juffurey

comments.text:
+TheSinnerpuppet Just because the restaurant is owned by Indians doesn't 
mean it's good quality food. I've been to restaurants like +Martin Kerr is 
talking about. Owned by Indians but the butter chicken taste like chicken 
boiled in ketchup. I live in Toronto, some of the indian restaurants are 
like that, then you got some real good ones. especially around Brampton (a 
city just outside Toronto)
comments.author: Xenophile C

comments.text:
+TheSinnerpuppet Not the case here in Edmonton- as far as I've seen they 
are all managed and staffed by Indian people, in the kitchen and out front.
comments.author: Martin Kerr

comments.text:
coz ...if u know most of the restaurants run in the name of indian are not 
owned by indians..its a pity...but true
comments.author: TheSinnerpuppet

comments.text:
+Xenophile C Thank you! I've used tomato puree which thickens the gravy as 
well as adds lovely colour.
comments.author: Maunika Gowardhan

comments.text:
Come over to India, New Delhi to be precise and taste what authentic Butter 
Chicken is suppose to be like. The food that people get in places like UK 
and USA in the name of Indian food is an outright travesty. Not only Butter 
Chicken there are so many other dishes that you will love, I'm sorry to say 
this recipe is a bastardized version of Butter Chicken, she used bloody 
canned tomato, that's not how you make Butter Chicken. Come over to Delhi 
if you're a big foodie and trust me you will not regret it.
comments.author: seanmcbride1

comments.text:
so true, when I saw this video, I was gonna say, finally someone who made 
this properly

comments.text: +Deepak Sharma Oookaay...
comments.author: shoutenry

comments.text: +Deepak Sharma Oh, I thought I already said that in my comment.
comments.author: shoutenry

comments.text:
+Deepak Sharma The separation of the chicken and gravy in makhani is 
traditional.

When it was first made as staff food it used leftover tandoori chicken.

Of course, you're probably right in that cooking the chicken and gravy 
together makes for a better tasting final product. 

Still, I often feel like the better texture of the separately cooked 
chicken is worth it over the veritable poaching in the mixed method.
comments.author: shoutenry

comments.text: Did she call you Jimmy? (:
comments.author: Marc Jensan

comments.text:
+Deepak Sharma it depends. A indian chef from punjab when i was in mumbai + 
the greatest vah chef said that boiling onions is a common practice in 
restaurants. Sometimes chefs also pure raw onions and cook in oil. 

Yes cashew nut paste can be made raw, but are sometimes boiled in 
restaurants before pureeing so they can thicken curries quicker without 
having a raw nutty taste in the final dish. 

How much onions are cooked will also determine the flavours. I guess we all 
have our little tips n tricks in the kitchen. It's the end result that 
really matter;)
comments.author: MrQuagmire26

comments.text:
+Deepak Sharma I boil onions and cashew nuts for about 30 min and blend 
into a paste. Then I fry the paste together with ginger/garlic paste and 
spices before adding tomatoes. Methi and a pinch of garam masala goes in at 
the end. Boiling the onions will give a lovely sweetness to the dish. And 
yeah, I also use a pinch of honey.
comments.author: MrQuagmire26

comments.text:
Jamie.. Am a big fan of yours. Congratulations to you and Maunika for 
putting up such a wonderful preparation. Just to add: Burn a small piece of 
coal and then put it in a small bowl. Then keep the bowl on top of the 
gravy and pour a little bit of butter on top of the burning coal. Then 
cover the butter chicken for 2-3 minutes. Once you open the covering, you 
would get the butter chicken real smoky.
comments.author: Dipyaman Basu

comments.text:
+MrQuagmire26 Who are you to say what is Indian and what is not? India is 
an enormous country and is home to over 1 billion people. Are you trying 
to tell us that there is just ONE way to make butter chicken? Don't be 
ridiculous! As for "authentic", where did Maunika use that word? She is 
showing us how SHE makes butter chicken in the way that SHE thinks is most 
delicious. Stop being so ridiculous and just ENJOY THE FOOD!!!!!!! That's 
what we are all here to do after all!
comments.author: albstralian

comments.text:
+MrQuagmire26 there's always that one minded person who spoils the comment 
smh
comments.author: Donell Clark

comments.text:

means gravy.

comments.text:

comments.text:
u can use but not sure about the color... bcz kashmiri chilli powder is the 
most appropriate for this dish.. its not too hot in taste but gives amazing

comments.text:
You can use any other chilli powder or curry powder (basaar) as a 
substitute for the Kashmiri chilli.
comments.author: Menezhaya

top_comment.text:
why is it named butter chicken? butter is like a very small ingredient, 
thats used to cook the onions not for flavor. and im betting that if you 
substituted it with something else you wouldn't even know lol﻿
top_comment.author: chop glitch

comments.text: its about the creaminess of dish .....its buttery
comments.author: what

comments.text:
none of the above reasons actually. The indian name is murgh makhani, which 
means chicken in makhani or makkhan. She put a lot of double cream in that 
gravy and traditional indian recipes have fresh double cream made from milk 
which forms the base of the gravy, giving it a creamy flavor and texture. I 
guess butter chicken serves better than double cream chicken? Or might be a 
mistranslation.
comments.author: blablabhu

comments.text:
Am pretty sure Gordon Ramsay did something like that years ago. Can't find 
it tho! :(
comments.author: PhantomAct

comments.text: +123gurtej or mustard oil
comments.author: Leo Watkins

comments.text:
I cook mine in butter and add abit more near the end. It gives it a buttery 
taste. Maybe not the most authentic way to cook it but it taste really good 
and similar too what u get at a good asian restaurant. Yoy cant get that 
taste with ghee. Ghee has a different taste altogether.
comments.author: sallybgum

comments.text:
Because usually the onions and the spices would be fried up in clarified 
butter or "ghee" in India. This is cooked in proper butter which really 
does change the flavour of the dish.
comments.author: 123gurtej

comments.text: because the chicken is being "buttered" up by the gravy ?

comments.author: Boston Prince

captions.text: Word up Foodtubers, Mr Oliver here. Today is a very exciting day
because I am gonna get the chance to cook with an incredible indian cook.
The lovely Maunika Gowardhan. Hello darling... Hi Jamie.
We're gonna cook some amazing food.
The dish is Murgh Makhani. So Murgh means chicken and Makhani means butter.
It's full of flavour. It's decadent. So you've got the sweet, sour, spicy, hot, tangy all of it.
What can I do to tell the story?
You can... Peeling, chopping? Yeah you're peeling and chopping
I can't believe you're following my guide! For a change.
What I need you to do is we'll first make the marinade for the chicken tikka itself.
so I've got your four cloves of garlic. Your pinch of peeled ginger
Half of this chilli please. Half of that chilli
So we'll make a little paste of that
That's perfect. Now, I've taken about four tablespoons of Greek low fat yogurt
and I've also added some chick pea flour, which is ground flour, so about two tablespoons
and we'll just give that a quick stir
Guys if you've never used ground flour before, it's just grounded down dry chick peas.
So no lumps in that Jamie. Nope
Sure? No, well... I am now
Ok along with that, just a few more ground spices.
So I'm using coriander. Just about a teaspoon isn't it?
Yeah a teaspoon. Pinch of Cinnamon.

now this is Kashmirri chilli powder. It's
really smoky
it's got a good amount of heat as well but it's got colour.
It's hot
and we've also got some cumin powder and this is a pinch of saffron
which actually adds the colour to the marinade as well
So in with all the ground spices
and a pinch of salt. Great to do this overnight, if you can in the refrigerator.
but if you cant then even 20 minutes, half an hour is perfectly fine.
So the ginger, the garlic and chilli in the marinade
Now, what do we do next. Do I just stir this in?
Mix it and then you add the chicken to it. Ok... you're going for chicken thighs
Why would you do that?
I think much more succulent cut of meat and also I find it's still quite moist when you add it to the gravy
So what's next? Next is to skewer them on. Ok.
Now we'll just grill this. You want the edges to be nice and charred and you want the meat to still be quite moist.
So once it's done then we can add it to the curry
Ok now we've made the gravy sauce for it. So add about half of this butter in the pan Jamie please.
and peel and grate half an inch of ginger and the chilli
Half these and de-seed and just length wise is brilliant.
Along with it and adding a few spices.
Can I have a little taste. Sure.
This is the outer... Ah Liquorice! Almost like that, but this is the outer covering of the cinnamon
and I've got six pods of green cardamom
and about 4/5 cloves, now this will add the warmth to the gravy
and they'll start to sizzle in the pan. Jamie if you could please chilli and the ginger.
Yes ma'am
Half of this onion and you don't want them to brown or colour, you just want them to become softened.
That's gorgeous. Three heap teaspoons of tomato puree
So you want that little bit of colour
Now the kushmirri chilli powder. So a good heap teaspoon of that and a good teaspoon of coriander powder as well.
Nice. So now all the spices are going in. So they're going to kind cook all the way through as well
Double cream and I think in some parts of the world you call it heavy cream
Basically this is the richer cream
I'm also adding some honey. So a teaspoon of honey.
There's a few more things I want to add to it. Dried vinaigrette leaves. Fresh coriander
and a pinch of salt. All we need to do is actually add the chicken to the sauce
Leave it to soak in all the flavours
So you can see the charred edges. Whose bits is what's actually going to add the flavour
Perfect. So... It smells incredible
Give it a stir please Jamie.
You can coat all the chicken so it soaks in all the flavours of the gravy as well.
You can add a little bit of Lemon juice
and how much would you like? That would be perfect... brilliant.
and it does give that curry a nice little finish
The colours are phenomenal... and it smells outragous
and we've got some salad so I've got a pickled onion salad, diced onions, lemon and salt.
and just some lettuce. Simple green lettuce. We've got our chutneys...
the reason we do this channel is because of this...
got some of the chicken and sauce. The meat is tender. Nice, moist and succulent.
Yay!
It's so good! Maunika... thankyou for coming into the world of Foodtube
Absolute pleasure
Wonderful authentic recipe.
A pleasure and privilege to cook for everybody and for you and with you... it's been brilliant.
Phenomenal. That's buttered chicken. Please, please try it.
Thankyou so much... Until next time... lots of love
